DOC.HEAD: Houston Police Chief Named NYC Police Commissioner
DOC.TEXT: Mayor-elect David Dinkins today named Houston Police Chief Lee P. Brown as the city's next police commissioner. Brown, 52, will lead the nation's biggest police force, with 30,000 members, seven times more than Houston's. He takes office Jan. 22, succeeding Richard Condon, who has held the post since Benjamin Ward retired in October. At a news conference today in Houston, Brown said he considers the New York City post a ``once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.'' ``Obviously it's the largest police department, and the opportunity to run the largest police department _ that's the challenge,'' Brown, chief of Houston's 4,500-member force since 1982. Brown, who is black, has been credited with easing racial tension in Houston. But the Houston force recently has been hit with allegations of racism and corruption, as well as controversy over shootings by officers. He is known to have opposed an all-civilian board to review complaints against police in Houston, while Dinkins favors the idea in New York. ``We didn't discuss it at great length,'' said Dinkins, who was elected New York City's first black mayor. ``He's someone who's concerned a lot about the behavior of police.'' Brown, only the second out-of-towner named New York police commissioner in 30 years, $110,000 a year in Houston and said he would receive the same here. He was previously public safety commissioner in Atlanta, an educator in criminal justice at Portland State University and Howard University, and a sheriff in Oregon.
